metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Post Master General, Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant filed a complaint against the 2nd respondent before the Add. Munsiff Magistrate of Jodhpur City under ss. 323 and 504 I.P.C.
2nd respondent was the Post Master General, Rajasthan and the appellant a clerk in the Head Post Office at Jodhpur. He was also the Divisional Secretary of National Union of Postal Employees.
Accused came on tour to Jodhpur on 25-10-1971. He arrived at the Head Post Office Jodhpur, in connection with the inspection at 5.45 P.M.
Complainant reached to submit his representation to the accused for cancelling his transfer, when the accused just sat in his jeep and the complainant started narrating his story.

Accused being enraged by this complaint, kicked him in his abdomen and abused him by saying 'Sale, Goonda, Badmash, on one hand you are complaining and on the other hand you are requesting for the cancellation of transfer.'
Complainant became very much enraged over this incident but he suppressed his anger because of being responsible citizen and to avoid any further disturbance.
After kicking and abusing the complainant the accused ran away in his jeep.

2nd respondent filed an application under S. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure praying that the court should not take cognizance of the offence without the sanction of the Government as the acts alleged, if at all done by the accused, were done while discharging his duties as a public servant.

Justice Mehta of the Rajasthan High Court allowed the revision petition filed by the 2nd respondent and set aside the order of the lower court holding that the 2nd respondent could not be prosecuted unless prior sanction of the Central Government had been obtained.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court against the High Court order.

legal_issues.text: Whether prior sanction under s.197 CrPC is necessary for taking cognizance of offences under ss.323 and 504 IPC against the 2nd respondent, a public servant, for the alleged acts of kicking and abusing the complainant.

petitioner_arguments.text: The alleged acts of kicking and abusing were not done in the execution of duty or purporting to be done in the execution of duty, hence no sanction under s.197 CrPC required.

respondent_arguments.text: The acts alleged, if at all done by the accused, were done while discharging his duties as a public servant, hence sanction under s.197 CrPC required before taking cognizance.

court_reasoning.text: The law regarding sanction under s.197 CrPC is well settled from Hori Ram Singh's case to Bhagwan Prasad Srivastava v. N.P. Misra. The intention is to prevent harassment of public servants. Applies to acts done or purporting to be done in execution of duty, even if dishonest intention or in excess, but not purely private acts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Offence must be in respect of an act done or purported to be done in discharge of official duty.

court_reasoning.text: Test: Whether the public servant can reasonably claim that what he does, he does in virtue of his office. There must be a reasonable connection between the act and the discharge of official duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: From Matajog Dobey v. H.C. Bhari: the act must bear such relation to the duty that the accused could lay a reasonable claim that he did it in the course of performance of his duty.

court_reasoning.text: Applying the test, the acts complained of i.e. kicking the complainant and abusing him, cannot be said to have been done in the course of performance of the 2nd respondent's duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: On facts alleged in complaint, acts not in purported exercise of duty.

court_reasoning.text: No opinion on truth or falsity of allegations. Necessity for sanction may arise later based on facts during inquiry or trial; it can depend from stage to stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere raising of defence not sufficient to require sanction at this stage.

holdings.text: No sanction under s.197 CrPC required at this stage for prosecution of 2nd respondent for alleged acts, as they do not purport to be in execution of official duty.

precedents_cited.relevance: Laid down scope of s.197 CrPC: not confined to acts directly in pursuance of duty; act constituting offence need not be inseparably connected; must attach to official character.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwan Prasad Srivastava v. N. P. Misra
precedents_cited.relevance: Reiterated that necessity for sanction may reveal itself in course of case progress.

precedents_cited.case_name: Matajog Dobey v. H. C. Bhari
precedents_cited.relevance: Test of reasonable connection between act and official duty; accused must lay reasonable claim it was in performance of duty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sarjoo Prasad v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Mere proposal to raise defence of act in execution of duty not sufficient to throw out case for want of sanction.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences alleged in complaint: voluntarily causing hurt and intentional insult.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires previous sanction for prosecution of public servant for act done in execution of duty or purporting to be so done.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed. Order of Rajasthan High Court set aside. Magistrate's order dismissing s.197 application restored. Prosecution may proceed without prior sanction at this stage, though necessity may arise later.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order quashed; cognizance permitted without sanction.

key_quotes.text: There must be a reasonable connection between the act and the discharge of official duty the act must bear such relation to the duty that the accused could lay a reasonable, but not a pretended or fanciful claim, that he did it in the course of the performance of his duty.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test applied to determine if sanction required under s.197 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: Applying this test it is difficult to say that the acts complained of i.e. of kicking the complainant and of abusing him, could be said to have been done in the course of performance of the 2nd respondents duty.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: A public servant can only be said to act or purport to act in the discharge of his official duty, if his act is such as to lie within the scope of his official duty. The test may well be whether the public servant, if challenged, can reasonably claim that, what he does, he does in virtue of his office.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test from Privy Council in Hori Ram Singh case.
